properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle has been observed across the area. Multiple reports of icy roads and sidewalks have been received. Patchy freezing drizzle may be mixed with light snow at times, and is expected to continue this afternoon and tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T10:56:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T18:57:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1673703082.2021
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County, Woodstock - Tillsonburg - Oxford County, Brantford - County of Brant, Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, City of Hamilton, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County, Stratford - Mitchell - Southern Perth County, Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County, Guelph - Erin - Southern Wellington County, Kitchener - Cambridge - Region of Waterloo, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County, Caledon, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow leading to reduced visibility is expected tonight near the Richardson mountains. Easterly winds will rise to 50 km/h gusting to 70 near the Richardson mountains leading to periods of blowing snow tonight. Winds will ease and visibility will improve Wednesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T03:40:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T11:41:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0158302911.2021
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of heavy rain will continue today for Howe Sound, the North Shore, and northeastern Metro Vancouver. An additional 30 to 40 mm is expected through this evening. A series of frontal systems continue to bring periods of rain to the south coast of BC today. Heavy rain will taper off this morning. However, another round of heavy rain will move in this afternoon and continue early this evening. Rain will then ease overnight. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T04:44:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T12:45:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3860511034.2021
Area: Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage will develop this afternoon, with gusts up to 90 km/h expected in wind prone areas. Winds will diminish this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T03:38:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T11:39:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4219022320.2021
Area: Yellowhead Co. near Cadomin and Robb, Clearwater Co. near Chungo Creek, Clearwater Co. near Nordegg and Big Horn Res., Clearwater Co. near Ya-Ha-Tinda Ranch, M.D. of Bighorn near Ghost River Wilderness, M.D. of Bighorn near Canmore Exshaw and Ghost Lake, Kananaskis Improvement District near Kananaskis Village, Kananaskis Improvement District near Highwood House
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong to severe winds Wednesday and Thursday along with a mix of wintery precipitation and blowing snow. A clipper system will cross Saskatchewan Wednesday resulting in widespread strong winds of 60 gusting 80 km/h across the southern half of the province. The strong winds will begin in the southwest Wednesday morning, expand eastward through the day, and generally continue into Thursday. Localized severe gusts to 100 km/h are possible - most likely Wednesday afternoon or evening - though exact timing and location remain unclear as the track of this system continues to evolve. In addition, a mix of scattered rain showers, potential freezing rain, and finally some snow will accompany the system. Amounts are generally expected to be low, but isolated snow squalls and banding could see local totals of 5 to 10 cm. With the strong winds ongoing across the south, visibilities will be reduced at times due to snow and blowing snow. The winds and lingering snow will both taper off late Thursday as the system finally departs the prairies. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T02:30:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T10:31:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2101821799.2021

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage will develop this afternoon, with wind gusts to 90 km/h expected in wind prone areas. The wind will diminish by Wednesday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle has been observed across the area this morning. Multiple reports of icy roads and sidewalks have been received. The freezing drizzle may be mixed with light snow at times, and is expected to become more patchy this afternoon. Freezing drizzle is possible again tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 50 to 70 mm of rain is expected today through Wednesday morning. Periods of rain will continue today, and will intensify tonight. Heavy rain will ease Wednesday morning. A series of frontal systems continue to bring periods of rain to the BC south coast today. Rain will intensify tonight as the frontal system pushes through the eastern Fraser Valley, and will ease Wednesday behind the front. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T04:50:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T12:51:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1005988899.2021
Area: Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A vigorous Pacific frontal system will bring significant amount of snow to Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass today through Wednesday. Total snow accumulations of 50 to 60 cm are forecast by Wednesday morning. Warm air moving into the region may lead to snow becoming mixed with rain tonight. The snow will continue through Wednesday afternoon with further accumulations expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T03:22:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T11:23:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1481191727.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow will begin early this afternoon and end Wednesday afternoon. Strong winds will cause very low visibilities in local blowing snow in wind prone areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Heavy snow is expected to develop early Wednesday morning and end by late Wednesday afternoon. Before the heavy snow, an area of freezing rain will pass through. However, there is significant uncertainty as to the track of the system, and warnings may be need to be adjusted. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T02:38:45-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix is expected over the highway passes of southern BC today through Wednesday. Expect mixed precipitation and rain falling on wet snow today. The rain will then change back to snow tonight or early Wednesday. Coquihalla Summit: Snow will change to rain this morning and back to snow after midnight. About 5 to 10 cm snow expected this morning with 30 mm of rain this afternoon and evening. 15 cm of snow can be expected on Wednesday. Allison Pass and Helmer Lake: Similar trend as Coquihalla Summit but with lesser rainfall and snowfall amounts. Okanagan Connector: The pass will likely remain above the snow level with total snowfall amount of 15 to 25 cm expected by Wednesday afternoon. Rogers Pass: 15 to 25 cm of snow before changing to rain late this evening. Periods of snow on Wednesday with another 5 to 10 cm. A strong warm front will bring a lot of moisture and increasing snow level to southern BC today and tonight. The trailing cold front will move across the region from the northwest to southeast on Wednesday, lowering the snow level and producing more snow over the highway passes. As the snow level can change significantly between different locations, the exact timing and snowfall amounts will vary. Please refer to the latest route forecast for updated details. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T03:35:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T11:36:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0927091226.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds that may cause damage will develop late this morning, with gusts up to 120 km/h possible this afternoon. Winds will diminish by Wednesday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T03:43:56-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre will cross southern Vancouver Island late this evening with northwest winds of 70 to 90 km/h developing over West Vancouver Island after midnight. Winds will ease on Wednesday morning as a ridge of high pressure builds onto the BC coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T10:47:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T18:48:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3219140142.2021
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre will cross southern Vancouver Island late this evening and move into the BC Interior overnight. Behind the low, strong winds will develop through Juan de Fuca Strait giving westerly winds of 70 km/h over areas of Greater Victoria near the strait that will persist into early Wednesday afternoon. Winds over the Southern Gulf Islands will rise to southwest 70 km/h after midnight and then ease on Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-13T10:47:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T18:48:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3520869112.2021
Area: Greater Victoria, Southern Gulf Islands
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system will bring strong winds over the northern sections of Haida Gwaii this morning. Southwesterly winds of 90 km/h gusting to 110 km/h will ease late this morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-12T23:04:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-12T12:11:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0460011295.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High levels of pollutants are expected to persist until Wednesday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadas website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montral, visit the Rseau de surveillance de la qualit de lair de la Ville de Montrals website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Qubec, visit the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociauxs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-13T19:04:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministre de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministre de la Sant et des Services sociaux, the Direction rgionale de sant publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lle-de-Montral, the City of Montral, 2021-01-12T20:49:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0662721842.2021
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Prade area, Trois-Rivires area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. The snow will start late Tuesday evening in the Whitecourt and Hinton areas, and overnight farther east. The snow should end early Wednesday afternoon. There is considerable uncertainty on location of the heaviest band of snow. Warnings may need to be shifted if the system develops farther south than expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
